properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A line of showers and thunderstorms is located from Newcastle to Port Weller and is moving east at 45 knots. This line has a history of producing wind gusts of 35 to 45 knots. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions will end this morning as winds diminish. However, fresh snow and strengthening winds from the west will lead to more blowing snow overnight into Saturday morning. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T18:29:14-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE, SMITHERS, QUESNEL AND VERNON The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake and Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-21T04:17:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-20T12:18:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2290956373.2020
Area: North Okanagan, Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Bulkley Valley, Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Summary:

Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds gusting up to 100 km/h beginning near noon today. In the wake of the warm front this morning, strong southwesterly winds gusting up to 100 km/h are forecast to develop. These strong winds will begin near noon today and continue for a few hours before shifting to the northwest and easing by early this evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will give zero visibilities in blowing snow today. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T23:59:52-00:00

Area: Waskaganish
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and rapidly falling temperatures today. The snow will taper off by this evening, with total snowfall amounts up to 10 cm expected. This morning, a cold front will sweep through with a fairly dramatic temperature drop from near zero degrees to well below. This may result in icy conditions on untreated surfaces. Gusty winds up to 60 km/h may also result in isolated power outages. If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T22:02:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T14:42:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2769422244.2020
Area: Gogama - Foleyet, Kirkland Lake - Englehart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall followed by heavy rain is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: southern and western Newfoundland. Total snowfall: generally 5 to 10 cm except a trace to 2 cm over the southern Avalon Peninsula. Total rainfall: 30 to 60 mm in the south and 15 to 25 mm in the west. Time span: this afternoon until overnight tonight in the west and southwest, and tonight in the south. Remarks: Snow has begun over southwestern Newfoundland and will spread northeastward through the day. The snow will change to rain at times heavy this afternoon in the southwest and this evening elsewhere. Conditions will improve by Saturday morning. Strong southerly winds and mild temperatures will accompany the rainfall to cause significant snowmelt and runoff, leading to potential flooding. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-21T05:15:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T13:16:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1779489900.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 11:26 a.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts. This line of severe thunderstorms is located from Freelton to Burford, moving east at 80 km/h. Locations impacted include: Hamilton, Brantford, Burlington, Ancaster, Dundas, Waterdown, Stoney Creek and Rockton. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:58:55-00:00

properties.Summary:

Locations: southwestern Newfoundland. Time span: this afternoon and early this evening. Remarks: local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinity of Cape St. George and Port au Port Bay. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Over 25 millimetres of rain is expected over higher elevations today. The rain, combined with the snowmelt, could accelerate runoff and increase the level of some rivers. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief strong wind gusts possible today. A strong cold front will sweep across the region today preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. The band will affect areas near Georgian Bay in the late morning or around noon, then move rapidly eastward to reach eastern Ontario in the mid afternoon. Winds gusts near or in excess of 90 km/h will be possible in some areas as the band moves through. Given that the showers and thunderstorms are expected to be scattered, strong wind gusts will only affect some areas. Where these strong winds develop, local power outages will be possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-21T01:59:41-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: Northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: until early afternoon. Remarks: Patchy freezing rain will continue over northeastern New Brunswick for another hour or two then change over to rain by as warmer air from the south finally makes its way into the region. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall amounts: 20 to 40 cm. Peak wind gusts: northwesterly 110 km/h. Locations: Postville-Makkovik to Natuashish. Timespan: tonight through Saturday. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will begin this afternoon and will persist through tonight and Saturday. Strong northwesterly winds will develop overnight tonight in the Natuashish area and will spread south to Postville-Makkovik by Saturday afternoon. These winds will combine with the fresh snowfall to reduce visibility at times to near zero in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Saturday night as the snow tapers off the winds begin to ease. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-21T05:43:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T13:44:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2187546080.2020

properties.Summary:
Description: Brief strong wind gusts possible today. A strong cold front will sweep across the region this morning into early this afternoon preceded by a band of scattered showers or thunderstorms. Scattered wind gusts near or in excess of 90 km/h will be possible as the band moves through. Given the scattered nature of the band, confidence in high winds gusts occurring in any given place is low. Where these strong winds develop, local power outages will likely occur. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely and may issue watches or warnings as required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-21T01:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T14:46:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3132806163.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow today. Additional snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 cm are expected before the snow tapers off early this afternoon. Northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will give local blowing and drifting snow, particularly over exposed areas. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T22:59:01-00:00
